trans-unit.source: How to use Queue storage from Node.js | Microsoft Azure
trans-unit.target: How to use Queue storage from Node.js | Microsoft Azure

trans-unit.source: Learn how to use the Azure Queue service to create and delete queues, and insert, get, and delete messages. Samples written in Node.js.
trans-unit.target: Learn how to use the Azure Queue service to create and delete queues, and insert, get, and delete messages. Samples written in Node.js.

trans-unit.source: This guide shows you how to perform common scenarios using the Microsoft Azure Queue service.
trans-unit.target: This guide shows you how to perform common scenarios using the Microsoft Azure Queue service.

trans-unit.source: The samples are written using the Node.js API.
trans-unit.target: The samples are written using the Node.js API.

trans-unit.source: The scenarios covered include inserting, peeking, getting, and deleting queue messages, as well as creating and deleting queues.
trans-unit.target: The scenarios covered include inserting, peeking, getting, and deleting queue messages, as well as creating and deleting queues.

trans-unit.source: Create a blank Node.js application.
trans-unit.target: Create a blank Node.js application.

trans-unit.source: For instructions creating a Node.js application, see [Create and deploy a Node.js application to an Azure Web Site], <linkText>Node.js Cloud Service[node.js cloud service]</linkText><title></title> (using Windows PowerShell), or [Web Site with WebMatrix].
trans-unit.target: For instructions creating a Node.js application, see [Create and deploy a Node.js application to an Azure Web Site], <linkText>Node.js Cloud Service[node.js cloud service]</linkText><title></title> (using Windows PowerShell), or [Web Site with WebMatrix].

trans-unit.source: To use Azure storage, you need the Azure Storage SDK for Node.js, which includes a set of convenience libraries that communicate with the storage REST services.
trans-unit.target: To use Azure storage, you need the Azure Storage SDK for Node.js, which includes a set of convenience libraries that communicate with the storage REST services.

trans-unit.source: Use a command-line interface such as PowerShell (Windows,) Terminal (Mac,) or Bash (Unix), navigate to the folder where you created your sample application.
trans-unit.target: Use a command-line interface such as PowerShell (Windows,) Terminal (Mac,) or Bash (Unix), navigate to the folder where you created your sample application.

trans-unit.source: Type npm install azure-storage in the command window.
trans-unit.target: Type npm install azure-storage in the command window.

trans-unit.source: Output from the command is similar to the following example.
trans-unit.target: Output from the command is similar to the following example.

trans-unit.source: You can manually run the ls command to verify that a node\_modules folder was created.
trans-unit.target: You can manually run the ls command to verify that a node\_modules folder was created.

trans-unit.source: Inside that folder you will find the azure-storage package, which contains the libraries you need to access storage.
trans-unit.target: Inside that folder you will find the azure-storage package, which contains the libraries you need to access storage.

trans-unit.source: Using Notepad or another text editor, add the following to the top the server.js file of the application where you intend to use storage:
trans-unit.target: Using Notepad or another text editor, add the following to the top the server.js file of the application where you intend to use storage:

trans-unit.source: The azure module will read the environment variables AZURE\STORAGE\ACCOUNT and AZURE\STORAGE\ACCESS\KEY, or AZURE\STORAGE\CONNECTION\STRING for information required to connect to your Azure storage account.
trans-unit.target: The azure module will read the environment variables AZURE\STORAGE\ACCOUNT and AZURE\STORAGE\ACCESS\KEY, or AZURE\STORAGE\CONNECTION\STRING for information required to connect to your Azure storage account.

trans-unit.source: If these environment variables are not set, you must specify the account information when calling createQueueService.
trans-unit.target: If these environment variables are not set, you must specify the account information when calling createQueueService.

trans-unit.source: For an example of setting the environment variables in the management portal for an Azure Website, see [Node.js Web Application with Storage]
trans-unit.target: For an example of setting the environment variables in the management portal for an Azure Website, see [Node.js Web Application with Storage]

trans-unit.source: The following code creates a QueueService object, which enables you to work with queues.
trans-unit.target: The following code creates a QueueService object, which enables you to work with queues.

trans-unit.source: Use the createQueueIfNotExists method, which returns the specified queue if it already exists or creates a new queue with the specified name if it does not already exist.
trans-unit.target: Use the createQueueIfNotExists method, which returns the specified queue if it already exists or creates a new queue with the specified name if it does not already exist.

trans-unit.source: If the queue is created, result is true.
trans-unit.target: If the queue is created, result is true.

trans-unit.source: If the queue exists, result is false.
trans-unit.target: If the queue exists, result is false.

trans-unit.source: Optional filtering operations can be applied to operations performed using QueueService.
trans-unit.target: Optional filtering operations can be applied to operations performed using QueueService.

trans-unit.source: Filtering operations can include logging, automatically retrying, etc. Filters are objects that implement a method with the signature:
trans-unit.target: Filtering operations can include logging, automatically retrying, etc. Filters are objects that implement a method with the signature:

trans-unit.source: After doing its preprocessing on the request options, the method needs to call "next" passing a callback with the following signature:
trans-unit.target: After doing its preprocessing on the request options, the method needs to call "next" passing a callback with the following signature:

trans-unit.source: In this callback, and after processing the returnObject (the response from the request to the server), the callback needs to either invoke next if it exists to continue processing other filters or simply invoke finalCallback otherwise to end up the service invocation.
trans-unit.target: In this callback, and after processing the returnObject (the response from the request to the server), the callback needs to either invoke next if it exists to continue processing other filters or simply invoke finalCallback otherwise to end up the service invocation.

trans-unit.source: Two filters that implement retry logic are included with the Azure SDK for Node.js, ExponentialRetryPolicyFilter and LinearRetryPolicyFilter.
trans-unit.target: Two filters that implement retry logic are included with the Azure SDK for Node.js, ExponentialRetryPolicyFilter and LinearRetryPolicyFilter.

trans-unit.source: The following creates a QueueService object that uses the ExponentialRetryPolicyFilter:
trans-unit.target: The following creates a QueueService object that uses the ExponentialRetryPolicyFilter:

trans-unit.source: To insert a message into a queue, use the createMessage method to create a new message and add it to the queue.
trans-unit.target: To insert a message into a queue, use the createMessage method to create a new message and add it to the queue.

trans-unit.source: You can peek at the message in the front of a queue without removing it from the queue by calling the peekMessages method.
trans-unit.target: You can peek at the message in the front of a queue without removing it from the queue by calling the peekMessages method.

trans-unit.source: By default, peekMessages peeks at a single message.
trans-unit.target: By default, peekMessages peeks at a single message.

trans-unit.source: The result contains the message.
trans-unit.target: The result contains the message.

trans-unit.source: Using peekMessages when there are no messages in the queue will not return an error, however no messages will be returned.
trans-unit.target: Using peekMessages when there are no messages in the queue will not return an error, however no messages will be returned.

trans-unit.source: Processing a message is a two-stage process:
trans-unit.target: Processing a message is a two-stage process:

trans-unit.source: Dequeue the message.
trans-unit.target: Dequeue the message.

trans-unit.source: Delete the message.
trans-unit.target: Delete the message.

trans-unit.source: To dequeue a message, use getMessages.
trans-unit.target: To dequeue a message, use getMessages.

trans-unit.source: This makes the messages invisible in the queue, so no other clients can process them.
trans-unit.target: This makes the messages invisible in the queue, so no other clients can process them.

trans-unit.source: Once your application has processed a message, call deleteMessage to delete it from the queue.
trans-unit.target: Once your application has processed a message, call deleteMessage to delete it from the queue.

trans-unit.source: The following example gets a message, then deletes it:
trans-unit.target: The following example gets a message, then deletes it:

trans-unit.source: By default, a message is only hidden for 30 seconds, after which it is visible to other clients.
trans-unit.target: By default, a message is only hidden for 30 seconds, after which it is visible to other clients.

trans-unit.source: You can specify a different value by using options.visibilityTimeout with getMessages.
trans-unit.target: You can specify a different value by using options.visibilityTimeout with getMessages.

trans-unit.source: Using getMessages when there are no messages in the queue will not return an error, however no messages will be returned.
trans-unit.target: Using getMessages when there are no messages in the queue will not return an error, however no messages will be returned.

trans-unit.source: You can change the contents of a message in-place in the queue using updateMessage.
trans-unit.target: You can change the contents of a message in-place in the queue using updateMessage.

trans-unit.source: The following example updates the text of a message:
trans-unit.target: The following example updates the text of a message:

trans-unit.source: There are two ways you can customize message retrieval from a queue:
trans-unit.target: There are two ways you can customize message retrieval from a queue:

trans-unit.source: options.numOfMessages - Retrieve a batch of messages (up to 32.)
trans-unit.target: options.numOfMessages - Retrieve a batch of messages (up to 32.)

trans-unit.source: options.visibilityTimeout - Set a longer or shorter invisibility timeout.
trans-unit.target: options.visibilityTimeout - Set a longer or shorter invisibility timeout.

trans-unit.source: The following example uses the getMessages method to get 15 messages in one call.
trans-unit.target: The following example uses the getMessages method to get 15 messages in one call.

trans-unit.source: Then it processes each message using a for loop.
trans-unit.target: Then it processes each message using a for loop.

trans-unit.source: It also sets the invisibility timeout to five minutes for all messages returned by this method.
trans-unit.target: It also sets the invisibility timeout to five minutes for all messages returned by this method.

trans-unit.source: The getQueueMetadata returns metadata about the queue, including the approximate number of messages waiting in the queue.
trans-unit.target: The getQueueMetadata returns metadata about the queue, including the approximate number of messages waiting in the queue.

trans-unit.source: To retrieve a list of queues, use listQueuesSegmented.
trans-unit.target: To retrieve a list of queues, use listQueuesSegmented.

trans-unit.source: To retrieve a list filtered by a specific prefix, use listQueuesSegmentedWithPrefix.
trans-unit.target: To retrieve a list filtered by a specific prefix, use listQueuesSegmentedWithPrefix.

trans-unit.source: If all queues cannot be returned, result.continuationToken can be used as the first parameter of listQueuesSegmented or the second parameter of listQueuesSegmentedWithPrefix to retrieve more results.
trans-unit.target: If all queues cannot be returned, result.continuationToken can be used as the first parameter of listQueuesSegmented or the second parameter of listQueuesSegmentedWithPrefix to retrieve more results.

trans-unit.source: To delete a queue and all the messages contained in it, call the deleteQueue method on the queue object.
trans-unit.target: To delete a queue and all the messages contained in it, call the deleteQueue method on the queue object.

trans-unit.source: To clear all messages from a queue without deleting it, use clearMessages.
trans-unit.target: To clear all messages from a queue without deleting it, use clearMessages.

trans-unit.source: Shared Access Signatures (SAS) are a secure way to provide granular access to queues without providing your storage account name or keys.
trans-unit.target: Shared Access Signatures (SAS) are a secure way to provide granular access to queues without providing your storage account name or keys.

trans-unit.source: SAS are often used to provide limited access to your queues, such as allowing a mobile app to submit messages.
trans-unit.target: SAS are often used to provide limited access to your queues, such as allowing a mobile app to submit messages.

trans-unit.source: A trusted application such as a cloud-based service generates a SAS using the generateSharedAccessSignature of the QueueService, and provides it to an untrusted or semi-trusted application.
trans-unit.target: A trusted application such as a cloud-based service generates a SAS using the generateSharedAccessSignature of the QueueService, and provides it to an untrusted or semi-trusted application.

trans-unit.source: For example, a mobile app.
trans-unit.target: For example, a mobile app.

trans-unit.source: The SAS is generated using a policy, which describes the start and end dates during which the SAS is valid, as well as the access level granted to the SAS holder.
trans-unit.target: The SAS is generated using a policy, which describes the start and end dates during which the SAS is valid, as well as the access level granted to the SAS holder.

trans-unit.source: The following example generates a new shared access policy that will allow the SAS holder to add messages to the queue, and expires 100 minutes after the time it is created.
trans-unit.target: The following example generates a new shared access policy that will allow the SAS holder to add messages to the queue, and expires 100 minutes after the time it is created.

trans-unit.source: Note that the host information must be provided also, as it is required when the SAS holder attempts to access the queue.
trans-unit.target: Note that the host information must be provided also, as it is required when the SAS holder attempts to access the queue.

trans-unit.source: The client application then uses the SAS with QueueServiceWithSAS to perform operations against the queue.
trans-unit.target: The client application then uses the SAS with QueueServiceWithSAS to perform operations against the queue.

trans-unit.source: The following example connects to the queue and creates a message.
trans-unit.target: The following example connects to the queue and creates a message.

trans-unit.source: Since the SAS was generated with add access, if an attempt were made to read, update or delete messages, an error would be returned.
trans-unit.target: Since the SAS was generated with add access, if an attempt were made to read, update or delete messages, an error would be returned.

trans-unit.source: You can also use an Access Control List (ACL) to set the access policy for a SAS.
trans-unit.target: You can also use an Access Control List (ACL) to set the access policy for a SAS.

trans-unit.source: This is useful if you wish to allow multiple clients to access the queue, but provide different access policies for each client.
trans-unit.target: This is useful if you wish to allow multiple clients to access the queue, but provide different access policies for each client.

trans-unit.source: An ACL is implemented using an array of access policies, with an ID associated with each policy.
trans-unit.target: An ACL is implemented using an array of access policies, with an ID associated with each policy.

trans-unit.source: The following example defines two policies; one for 'user1' and one for 'user2':
trans-unit.target: The following example defines two policies; one for 'user1' and one for 'user2':

trans-unit.source: The following example gets the current ACL for myqueue, then adds the new policies using setQueueAcl.
trans-unit.target: The following example gets the current ACL for myqueue, then adds the new policies using setQueueAcl.

trans-unit.source: This approach allows:
trans-unit.target: This approach allows:

trans-unit.source: Once the ACL has been set, you can then create a SAS based on the ID for a policy.
trans-unit.target: Once the ACL has been set, you can then create a SAS based on the ID for a policy.

trans-unit.source: The following example creates a new SAS for 'user2':
trans-unit.target: The following example creates a new SAS for 'user2':

trans-unit.source: Now that you've learned the basics of queue storage, follow these links to learn about more complex storage tasks.
trans-unit.target: Now that you've learned the basics of queue storage, follow these links to learn about more complex storage tasks.
